title: Galatians Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Galatians chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Galatians Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Galatians Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:4, who did God send forth when the fullness of time was come?
questions.correctAnswer: His Son
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:4 states that God sent forth His Son when the fullness of time was come.

questions.question: In Galatians 4:6, what does the Spirit of God's Son cry in our hearts?
questions.correctAnswer: Abba, Father
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:6 says that the Spirit of His Son cries 'Abba, Father' in our hearts.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 4:7 teaches that if you are a son, you are also an heir of God through Christ.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:7 clearly states that if you are a son, then you are an heir of God through Christ.

questions.question: Who were the two sons of Abraham mentioned in Galatians 4:22?
options: One by a bondmaid, one by a freewoman
One by a servant, one by a queen
questions.correctAnswer: One by a bondmaid, one by a freewoman
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:22 explains that Abraham had two sons: one by a bondmaid and the other by a freewoman.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:10, what do some observe?
questions.correctAnswer: Days, months, times, and years
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:10 states that some observe days, months, times, and years.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Galatians 4:5: 'To redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: sons
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:5 says that Christ was sent to redeem those under the law so that we might receive the adoption of sons.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:9, after knowing God, what do some turn back to?
questions.correctAnswer: Weak and beggarly elements
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:9 describes turning back to weak and beggarly elements after knowing God.

questions.question: Who does Galatians 4:15 say the people would have given their own eyes to if possible?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:15 says the people would have plucked out their own eyes and given them to Paul if it had been possible.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 4:8 says that before knowing God, people served those who by nature are gods.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:8 states that before knowing God, people served those which by nature are no gods.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:24, what do the two sons of Abraham represent?
questions.correctAnswer: Two covenants
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:24 explains that the two sons are an allegory representing two covenants.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:26, who is described as free and the mother of us all?
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem which is above
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:26 states that Jerusalem which is above is free and is the mother of us all.

questions.question: In Galatians 4:1, how is an heir described while he is a child?
questions.correctAnswer: No different from a servant
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:1 says the heir as long as he is a child differs nothing from a servant.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 4:16 asks if Paul has become their enemy because he tells them the truth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:16 questions if Paul has become their enemy for telling the truth.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:19, what is Paul doing for his little children until Christ be formed in them?
questions.correctAnswer: Travails in birth again
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:19 says Paul travailed in birth again until Christ be formed in them.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:31, who are we children of?
questions.correctAnswer: The freewoman
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:31 states that we are not children of the bondwoman but of the freewoman.

medium.title: Galatians Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Galatians Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling like a servant rather than an heir of God. Based on Galatians 4, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them about their identity?
options: They are no longer a servant but a son and an heir of God through Christ.
They must continue to serve others to earn their inheritance.
Their status depends on their works and obedience to the law.
They remain under tutors and governors until the appointed time.
questions.correctAnswer: They are no longer a servant but a son and an heir of God through Christ.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:7 clearly states that believers are no longer servants but sons and heirs of God through Christ. This encourages trust in God’s grace and identity in Christ rather than legalistic service.

questions.question: How does Galatians 4 teach us about God’s timing in the work of redemption?
options: God sent His Son at the fullness of time to redeem those under the law.
God redeems people immediately without any appointed time.
Redemption depends on human effort and perfect timing.
The Son came before the appointed time to redeem mankind.
questions.correctAnswer: God sent His Son at the fullness of time to redeem those under the law.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:4-5 explains that God sent His Son when the fullness of time was come, to redeem those under the law and adopt them as sons, teaching us to trust God’s perfect timing in salvation.

questions.question: A believer struggles with returning to old legalistic practices. Based on Galatians 4, what reason does Paul give to discourage this?
options: It leads to bondage under weak and beggarly elements.
It brings greater spiritual freedom and joy.
It is necessary for salvation and acceptance.
It shows maturity in faith and obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to bondage under weak and beggarly elements.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:9 warns that returning to observing days and rituals leads to bondage under weak and beggarly elements, encouraging believers to rely on the freedom in Christ.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4, what role does the Spirit of God play in the life of believers?
options: The Spirit is sent into their hearts, crying 'Abba, Father,' affirming sonship.
The Spirit condemns believers for their past sins.
The Spirit requires strict adherence to the law.
The Spirit keeps believers in fear of punishment.
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit is sent into their hearts, crying 'Abba, Father,' affirming sonship.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:6 teaches that because believers are sons, God sends the Spirit of His Son into their hearts, enabling them to call God 'Abba, Father,' highlighting intimate relationship and assurance.

questions.question: How does Paul describe his relationship with the Galatians concerning his gospel ministry in Galatians 4?
options: He preached the gospel to them despite his physical infirmity and they received him like an angel.
He preached only when he was strong and healthy.
He was rejected by them because of his weakness.
He demanded financial support from them for his ministry.
questions.correctAnswer: He preached the gospel to them despite his physical infirmity and they received him like an angel.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:13-14 reveals Paul’s infirmity when he first preached to them, yet they did not despise or reject him but received him as an angel, showing humility and grace in ministry.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 4 teaches that believers should zealously pursue good things always, not only when the apostle Paul is present.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:18 encourages believers to be zealously affected always in good things, not just in Paul’s presence, teaching consistent Christian devotion and growth.

questions.question: How does Paul describe his spiritual concern for the Galatians in Galatians 4?
options: He travailed in birth again until Christ be formed in them.
He is indifferent to their spiritual condition.
He rejoices that they no longer need instruction.
He wants them to rely only on the law.
questions.correctAnswer: He travailed in birth again until Christ be formed in them.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:19 shows Paul’s deep pastoral concern likened to a mother in labor, emphasizing the importance of Christ’s formation within believers for spiritual maturity.

questions.question: What does Paul ask the Galatians about their desire to be under the law in Galatians 4?
options: Do they not hear the law?
Are they perfectly keeping the law?
Is the law unnecessary for salvation?
Have they replaced the law with tradition?
questions.correctAnswer: Do they not hear the law?
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:21 challenges those desiring to be under the law to listen and understand what the law truly says, urging discernment and obedience to God’s covenant.

questions.question: In Galatians 4, Paul uses the story of Abraham’s two sons as an allegory. What do the two sons represent?
options: The two covenants: one from Mount Sinai leading to bondage, and the other of promise.
Two different ethnic groups with equal inheritance.
Two laws given at different times.
questions.correctAnswer: The two covenants: one from Mount Sinai leading to bondage, and the other of promise.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:22-24 explains the allegory where the son of the bondwoman represents the covenant from Mount Sinai that leads to bondage, and the son of the freewoman represents the covenant of promise.

questions.question: What encouragement does Galatians 4 give about the spiritual Jerusalem?
options: The Jerusalem above is free and is the mother of us all.
The earthly Jerusalem is the true home of the believer.
Believers should return to Jerusalem to keep the law.
Jerusalem above is in bondage with her children.
questions.correctAnswer: The Jerusalem above is free and is the mother of us all.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:26 contrasts the earthly Jerusalem in bondage with the Jerusalem above, which is free and mother to all believers, symbolizing spiritual freedom and unity in Christ.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 4, believers are children of the bondwoman and thus under bondage.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:31 clearly states that believers are not children of the bondwoman (the slave woman) but of the free woman, indicating their freedom in Christ and not bondage.

questions.question: Paul expresses concern about his labor among the Galatians. What is his fear according to Galatians 4?
options: That his labor has been bestowed in vain if they turn away.
That they will become too zealous in good works.
That they will forget the law completely.
That they will reject all spiritual authority.
questions.correctAnswer: That his labor has been bestowed in vain if they turn away.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:11 reveals Paul’s fear that his efforts may have been in vain if they abandon the gospel and return to legalistic bondage, encouraging perseverance in faith.

questions.question: How does Galatians 4 describe the behavior of some who zealously influence the Galatians?
options: They zealously affect others, but not for good; they seek to exclude the believers for their own benefit.
They encourage genuine love and freedom in Christ.
They teach humility and contentment in all circumstances.
They serve the church faithfully and selflessly.
questions.correctAnswer: They zealously affect others, but not for good; they seek to exclude the believers for their own benefit.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:17 explains that some zealously affect the Galatians with bad intent, seeking to exclude them to gain advantage, warning believers to be discerning.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Galatians 4, the son of the bondwoman was born _____, but the son of the freewoman was born by promise.
questions.correctAnswer: after the flesh
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:23 states that the son of the bondwoman was born after the flesh, indicating natural birth, whereas the son of the freewoman was born by promise, symbolizing spiritual promise.

questions.question: What practical lesson about spiritual warfare and perseverance does Galatians 4 teach through the example of Isaac and Ishmael?
options: The son born after the flesh persecuted the son born after the Spirit, reflecting ongoing spiritual conflict.
Both sons lived in peace and harmony, showing unity in faith.
Legalistic observance protects from spiritual attack.
questions.correctAnswer: The son born after the flesh persecuted the son born after the Spirit, reflecting ongoing spiritual conflict.
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:29 likens the persecution of Isaac by Ishmael to the spiritual conflict believers face, encouraging perseverance and faith in the Spirit’s promises.

hard.title: Galatians Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Galatians Chapter 4.

questions.question: In Galatians 4, Paul uses the story of Abraham's two sons to illustrate what theological concept?
options: The contrast between law and promise
questions.correctAnswer: The contrast between law and promise
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:22-24 presents the allegory of Abraham's two sons to symbolize two covenants: one from Mount Sinai (law) and one of promise, illustrating the difference between bondage and freedom.

questions.question: What does Paul mean when he says, 'God sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father'?
options: That believers receive intimate adoption as God's children
That the Spirit replaces the law
That believers must obey the law
That God is distant and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: That believers receive intimate adoption as God's children
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:6 indicates that the Spirit of God's Son enables believers to address God intimately as 'Abba, Father,' signifying their status as adopted children of God.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:4-5, why was Jesus sent 'made under the law'?
options: To redeem those under the law and enable adoption as sons
To establish a new law for the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: To redeem those under the law and enable adoption as sons
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:4-5 explains that Jesus was sent under the law to redeem those who were under it so that they might receive the adoption of sons, highlighting redemption and adoption themes.

questions.question: What does Paul warn the Galatians about in Galatians 4:9-10?
options: Returning to observing weak and beggarly elements like days and months
Ignoring the teachings of the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: Returning to observing weak and beggarly elements like days and months
questions.explanation: In Galatians 4:9-10, Paul warns against reverting to legalistic observances of days, months, and times, which he calls weak and beggarly elements leading to bondage.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The one from the mount Sinai, which gendereth to ____________, which is Agar.'
questions.correctAnswer: bondage
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:24 describes the covenant from Mount Sinai as producing bondage, represented allegorically by Agar (Hagar).

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul referring to the Galatians as 'my little children, of whom I travail in birth again'?
options: He expresses deep pastoral concern and desire for their spiritual maturity
He is calling them immature believers who must be rebaptized
He wants them to leave the church
questions.correctAnswer: He expresses deep pastoral concern and desire for their spiritual maturity
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:19 uses childbirth imagery to show Paul's intense labor and desire for Christ to be formed in the believers, indicating deep pastoral care.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 4:7, being a son makes one an heir of God through Christ.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:7 clearly states that if one is a son, then one is also an heir of God through Christ.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the Galatians' previous spiritual condition before knowing God in Galatians 4:8?
options: They served beings that are no gods by nature
They were already free children of God
They were perfect in the law
questions.correctAnswer: They served beings that are no gods by nature
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:8 states that before knowing God, the Galatians served those who by nature are no gods, referring to idolatry or false spiritual powers.

questions.question: In the allegory of Galatians 4:22-31, who does the son born of the bondwoman represent?
options: Those born according to the flesh under the law
Those born by promise under grace
questions.correctAnswer: Those born according to the flesh under the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:23 uses the son of the bondwoman to represent those born according to the flesh, symbolizing people under the law and bondage.

questions.question: What does Paul fear about his labor among the Galatians in Galatians 4:11?
options: That his efforts might have been in vain
That they will become famous teachers
That they will reject the gospel completely
questions.correctAnswer: That his efforts might have been in vain
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:11 reveals Paul's concern that the work he has done preaching to them might have been wasted if they turn away.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the zeal of some who would exclude the Galatians in Galatians 4:17?
options: They zealously affect you, but not well
They are full of love and grace
They encourage freedom from the law
questions.correctAnswer: They zealously affect you, but not well
questions.explanation: In Galatians 4:17, Paul states that some zealously influence the Galatians, but with bad intent, aiming to exclude them for their own gain.

questions.question: What allegorical meaning does Paul attach to 'Jerusalem which is above' in Galatians 4:26?
options: It is free and the mother of us all
It is in bondage with her children
It is the mount Sinai covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It is free and the mother of us all
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:26 describes the heavenly Jerusalem as free and the spiritual mother of all believers, contrasting with the earthly Jerusalem in bondage.

questions.question: Which phrase in Galatians 4:15 indicates the Galatians' previous affection towards Paul?
options: They would have plucked out their own eyes and given them to me
questions.correctAnswer: They would have plucked out their own eyes and given them to me
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:15 shows the intense affection the Galatians had for Paul earlier, willing to give up their own eyes for him.

questions.question: What cultural practice is Paul referring to when he talks about being 'under tutors and governors until the time appointed of the father'?
questions.correctAnswer: Guardianship of heirs until majority
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:2 reflects Greco-Roman legal customs where a child heir was under guardians until reaching adulthood, illustrating spiritual immaturity before Christ.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Now we, brethren, as Isaac was, are the children of __________.'
questions.correctAnswer: promise
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:28 states that believers are children of promise, like Isaac, emphasizing the theme of divine promise over fleshly descent.

theological.title: Galatians Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Galatians Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:1, what is the status of an heir while he is still a child?
options: He is like a servant despite being lord of all
He is the full master of his inheritance
He has no rights at all
questions.correctAnswer: He is like a servant despite being lord of all
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:1 teaches that the heir, while still a child, differs nothing from a servant even though he is lord of all. This illustrates the concept of spiritual immaturity and subjection before adoption as sons (Romans 8:15; Ephesians 1:5; Hebrews 2:10; John 1:12).

questions.question: What did God send forth at the fullness of time according to Galatians 4:4?
options: His Son, made of a woman, made under the law
An angel to reveal the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: His Son, made of a woman, made under the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:4 states that God sent forth His Son, born of a woman and made under the law, emphasizing the incarnation and fulfillment of the law through Christ (John 1:14; Philippians 2:7; Hebrews 2:14; Matthew 5:17).

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:5, what is the purpose of Christ's redemption?
options: To redeem those under the law so we might receive adoption as sons
To establish a new earthly kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: To redeem those under the law so we might receive adoption as sons
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:5 teaches that Christ's redemptive work was to free those under the law so that believers might receive sonship, aligning with the doctrine of justification and adoption (Romans 8:15; Ephesians 1:5; Titus 3:7; John 1:12).

questions.question: What does Galatians 4:6 say God has sent into the hearts of believers?
options: The Spirit of His Son, crying Abba, Father
The spirit of fear and bondage
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of His Son, crying Abba, Father
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:6 reveals the sending of the Spirit of God's Son into the hearts of believers, enabling them to cry 'Abba, Father,' indicating intimate sonship and the presence of the Holy Spirit (Romans 8:15-16; 2 Corinthians 1:22; Ephesians 1:13-14; John 14:16-17).

questions.question: In Galatians 4:7, what status is given to believers as a result of being sons?
options: They are no longer servants but sons and heirs of God through Christ
They remain servants under the law
They are only servants until judgment
questions.correctAnswer: They are no longer servants but sons and heirs of God through Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:7 states that believers are no longer servants but sons, and as sons, heirs of God through Christ, highlighting the doctrine of adoption and inheritance in grace (Romans 8:17; Hebrews 12:7-8; John 1:12; Ephesians 1:11).

questions.question: What does Paul express fear about in Galatians 4:11 regarding his labor among the Galatians?
options: That his labor might have been in vain
That they would follow false teachers
questions.correctAnswer: That his labor might have been in vain
questions.explanation: Paul fears that his work preaching the gospel may have been wasted if the Galatians turn back to legalism, as stated in Galatians 4:11. This concern reflects the biblical theme of perseverance in faith (1 Corinthians 15:58; Philippians 2:16; 2 Timothy 4:7; Hebrews 6:11-12).

questions.question: In Galatians 4:21-22, Paul uses the story of Abraham's two sons to illustrate what theological point?
options: The two covenants: one from Mount Sinai leading to bondage, and the other by promise
The difference between Jewish and Gentile believers
The superiority of the Mosaic Law over the promise
The futility of faith apart from works
questions.correctAnswer: The two covenants: one from Mount Sinai leading to bondage, and the other by promise
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:21-22 uses Abraham's two sons as an allegory for the two covenants: the covenant from Sinai that brings bondage and the covenant of promise, teaching the contrast between law and grace (Hebrews 8:6-7; Romans 4:13; Exodus 19; Jeremiah 31:31).

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:24-25, what does Agar (Hagar) represent in the allegory?
options: The covenant from Mount Sinai which leads to bondage
The covenant of grace and freedom
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant from Mount Sinai which leads to bondage
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:24-25 presents Agar as a figure representing the covenant from Mount Sinai that produces bondage, symbolizing the law's inability to bring freedom (Exodus 19; Romans 7:6; Hebrews 12:18-21; 2 Corinthians 3:7-9).

questions.question: What does the 'Jerusalem which is above' represent in Galatians 4:26?
options: The free woman who is the mother of all believers
The earthly city under the law
The kingdom of Israel in exile
questions.correctAnswer: The free woman who is the mother of all believers
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:26 identifies the Jerusalem above as the free woman, symbolizing the heavenly city and spiritual freedom for all believers, consonant with Hebrews 12:22-24; Revelation 21; Isaiah 51:3; Psalm 87:5-7.

questions.question: In Galatians 4:29-30, what conflict is illustrated by the relationship between the son of the bondwoman and the son of the freewoman?
options: The persecution of the spiritual child by the fleshly child
The unity of all believers in Christ
The equality of law and promise
The fulfillment of the law in the flesh
questions.correctAnswer: The persecution of the spiritual child by the fleshly child
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:29-30 portrays the conflict where the son born according to the flesh persecutes the son born through the Spirit, symbolizing the opposition between law-based religion and the gospel of grace (Genesis 16-21; Romans 8:5-9; 2 Corinthians 12:7; John 15:18-20).

questions.question: According to Galatians 4:31, who are believers identified as children of?
questions.correctAnswer: The free woman
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:31 concludes that believers are children not of the bondwoman (law) but of the free woman, affirming the doctrine of freedom in Christ and spiritual sonship (Romans 8:15; 2 Corinthians 3:17; John 8:36; Galatians 5:1).

questions.question: What does Paul admonish the Galatians for doing in Galatians 4:9?
options: Turning again to weak and beggarly elements to be in bondage
Ignoring the teachings of the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: Turning again to weak and beggarly elements to be in bondage
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:9 reproves the Galatians for returning to 'weak and beggarly elements,' meaning legalistic observances that enslave instead of liberate, reflecting themes in Romans 6:14; Hebrews 10:1; Colossians 2:20-23; 2 Timothy 3:5.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'zeal' mentioned in Galatians 4:17-18?
options: They are zealously affected but not for good; whereas Paul encourages zeal for good things
questions.correctAnswer: They are zealously affected but not for good; whereas Paul encourages zeal for good things
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:17-18 contrasts false teachers' misguided zeal with Paul's encouragement to be zealous for good, highlighting the importance of proper motive and doctrine (Romans 12:11; Titus 2:14; Philippians 3:13-14; 1 Corinthians 9:26).

questions.question: What does Paul describe himself as doing in Galatians 4:19 for his spiritual children?
options: Travailing in birth until Christ is formed in them
questions.correctAnswer: Travailing in birth until Christ is formed in them
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:19 uses the metaphor of travail in birth to describe Paul's intense pastoral care until Christ is fully formed in believers, reflecting sanctification and Christlikeness (1 Corinthians 3:6; Philippians 1:6; Colossians 1:28; Ephesians 4:13).

questions.question: How does Paul describe the reception he received from the Galatians in Galatians 4:14?
options: They did not despise or reject him but received him as an angel of God, even as Christ Jesus
They rejected him and his message
They were indifferent to his presence
They welcomed him because of his wealth
questions.correctAnswer: They did not despise or reject him but received him as an angel of God, even as Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Galatians 4:14 shows the initial warm reception Paul received, likening it to being received as an angel or Christ Himself, reflecting the honor given to apostles and messengers (Acts 10:30; Hebrews 13:2; Matthew 28:20; John 13:20).
